address.addressline: Email: Manuscripts: hay@brown.edu; University Archives: archives@brown.edu

did.abstract: The Merton Stoltz Files include office files, correspondence, and committee files dated from 1959 to 1978. It includes materials from various offices, speeches, projects, and committees regarding the comprehensive involvement of a Provost at the University.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Note
bioghist.p: Merton Philip Stoltz (1913-1989), provost and acting president of Brown University, was born in Glidden, Wisconsin, on March 28, 1913. He graduated from the University of Minnesota in 1934 and earned a master’s degree at Brown in 1936. After earning his Ph.D. at Minnesota in 1941, he returned to Brown as assistant professor of economics. He was named full professor in 1950. He was chairman of the Department of Economics from 1956 to 1964, associate dean of the Graduate School from 1960 to 1964, and dean of the University from 1964 to 1966. As dean he was actively involved in proposals to the Ford Foundation and in the beginnings of the medical education program. One of the first acts of President Heffner on his arrival was to appoint Stoltz provost of the University, a post which had been vacant since June of 1965. In announcing the appointment Heffner said of his choice, “His integrity, his vision, his sensitivity to Brown traditions, and his demonstrated capacity for leadership make him ideally qualified for the position of principal academic office of this great University.” He was three times acting president of Brown, serving in 1969-70 between the presidencies of Heffner and Hornig, in the summer of 1972 while President Hornig recovered from a heart attack, and in 1976 between the presidencies of Hornig and Swearer. He retired in 1978. As an economist Stoltz was chosen to head the Special Providence Committee on Municipal Revenue in 1957 and served on the Rhode Island Fiscal Study Commission in 1961. Tougaloo College awarded him an honorary LL.D. degree in 1977, and at Brown’s Commencement that year he received a standing ovation on the announcement by President Swearer of the establishment of the Merton P. Stoltz Professorship. Brown awarded him an honorary LL.D. degree in 1978. He died on August 7, 1989 in Providence.

scopecontent.p: The papers are arranged into 19 series:
Series 1. Outgoing Correspondence (1965-1977): this series includes a chronological arrangement of mostly professional and collegial correspondence.

Series 2. Files: 1963-1965 (1959-1971): this series includes numerous files, arranged alphabetically, from Stoltz’s responsibilities in the University. The series is divided into four sub-series: general, foundations, committees, and academic departments.

Series 3. Files: 1965-1966 (1960-1967): this series includes numerous files, arranged alphabetically, from Stoltz’s responsibilities in the University. The series is divided into three sub-series: committees, general, and academic departments.

Series 4. Files: 1966-1967 (1965-1968): this series includes numerous files, arranged alphabetically, from Stoltz’s responsibilities in the University. The series is divided into three sub-series: committees, general, and academic departments.

Series 5. Files: 1967-1968 (1964-1968): this series includes numerous files, arranged alphabetically, from Stoltz’s responsibilities in the University. The series is divided into three sub-series: committees, general, and academic departments.

Series 6. Files: 1968-1969 (1967-1969): this series includes numerous files, arranged alphabetically, from Stoltz’s responsibilities in the University. The series is divided into three sub-series: committees, general, and academic departments.

Series 7. Files: 1969-1970 (1969-1970): this series includes numerous files concerning committees at Brown University, including committees on community relations, curricular philosophy, student strikes, and Tougaloo College.

Series 8. Files: 1970-1971 (1970-1971): this series includes numerous files, arranged mostly alphabetically, from Stoltz’s responsibilities in the University. The series is divided into two sub-series: committees and academic departments.

Series 9. Files: 1971-1972 (1971-1972): this series includes numerous files, arranged mostly alphabetically, from Stoltz’s responsibilities in the University. The series is divided into two sub-series: committees and academic departments.

Series 10. Files: 1972-1973 (1972-1973): this series includes numerous files, arranged mostly alphabetically, from Stoltz’s responsibilities in the University. The series is divided into two sub-series: committees and academic departments.

Series 11. Files: 1973-1974 (1973-1974): this series includes numerous files, arranged alphabetically, from Stoltz’s responsibilities in the University. The series is divided into two sub-series: general and academic departments.

Series 12. Files: 1974-1975 (1974-1975): this series includes numerous files, arranged alphabetically, from Stoltz’s responsibilities in the University. The series is divided into two sub-series: general and academic departments.

Series 13. Files: 1975-1976 (1975-1976): this series includes numerous files, arranged alphabetically, from Stoltz’s responsibilities in the University. The series is divided into two sub-series: general and academic departments.

Series 14. Files: 1976-1977 (1976-1977): this series includes numerous files, arranged alphabetically, from Stoltz’s responsibilities in the University. The series is divided into two sub-series: general and academic departments.

Series 15. Files: 1977-1978 (1977-1978): this series includes numerous files, arranged alphabetically, from Stoltz’s responsibilities in the University. The series is divided into two sub-series: general and academic departments.
Series 16. Historical Files (1968-1973): this short series includes documents concerning budget request forms, black student enrollment, and other planning committees.

Series 17. Committees (1973-1978): this series includes files from several discussing policy at Brown, including an academic policy, calendar, library, and promotion committees. The series is arranged chronologically.

Series 18. Internal Committees (1977-1978): this series contains documents concerning administrative committees. Included are documents from investment committees, faculty meetings, audit committees, and documents directly about Merton Stoltz. The series is mostly arranged chronologically.

Series 19. Grants (1964-1977): this series contains documents and files concerning several grant applications and programs. Most documents are applications for grants for the construction of university buildings, including the Sciences Library, Pembroke Dorms, Art Building, and Geo-Math Complex.

userestrict.p: All researchers seeking to publish materials from the collections of the John Hay Library are requested to complete a Notice of Intent to Publish, prior to reproducing, quoting, or otherwise publishing any portion or extract from this collection. Although Brown University has physical ownership of the collection and the materials contained therein, it does not claim literary rights. It is up to the researcher to determine the owners of the literary rights and to obtain any necessary permissions from them.

accessrestrict.p: There are no restrictions on access, except that the collection can only be seen by prior appointment. Some materials may be stored off-site and cannot be produced on the same day on which they are requested.

prefercite.p: Merton Stoltz Files, OF-1CA-S2, Brown University Library.

arrangement.p: This collection is divided into 19 series and further subseries. Most series are arranged either chronologically or alphabetically.
